Name: Amulet of a ritual blade
Description: Simple serpentine amulet in the form of a blade named in Egyptian the peseshkaf. This was used in the ritual to consecrate statues and coffins, the Opening of the Mouth. Its origins are obscure, but the shape resembles roughly certain forked flints of the Predynastic Period. Amulets in this form occur earlier, but only in the Late Period did it come into regular funerary use as part of the large sets of amulets placed on the body in mummification.
